newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian confirmed as world's oldest loves to sing.
newsitem.headline: Canadian confirmed as world's oldest loves to sing.

text.p: Marie-Louise Meilleur, the 116-year-old Canadian woman confirmed by the Guinness Book of Records on Thursday as the world's oldest person, is blind and deaf, but still loves to sing.

"When we go see her, she sings, 'C'est le mois de Marie' (It's the Virgin Mary's month).' And she sings very loud! She is very religious," Meilleur's step-granddaughter Nicole Bossi told Reuters on Thursday.
Meilleur, who lives in a nursing home in Corbeil in northern Ontario, will turn 117 on Aug. 29.
Born Marie-Louise Fibronie Chassi in 1880 in Kamouraska, Quebec, Meilleur has taken over the age record from Frenchwoman Jeanne Calmant, who died earlier this month at the age of 122.

Meilleur has more than 300 known descendants spread over six generations. She was married for the first time in 1900 to a Kamouraska fisherman, Etienne Leclerc. They had six children before her husband died of pneumonia in 1911.
She later married Hector Meilleur, a lumber worker. The couple settled in northern Ontario and she had six more children.
Meilleur has outlived her second husband and eight of her 12 children.
Bossi, when asked the secret of her step-grandmother's longevity, said: "She often says: 'Work and prayer.' But I know that she doesn't like meat. She has disdain for that."
She added that there may also be "something about the air in Kamouraska," a village about 93 miles (150 km) east of Quebec City, the capital of Canada's French-speaking province of Quebec.
After Calment's death on Aug. 4, Bossi sent Guinness's office in London many of Meilleur's documents, including her birth certificate and her entry in the 1881 Canadian census.
